div.p: A38 Royal Geographical Society of Australasia (Vic. Branch) papers, Mitchell Library, State Library of New South Wales, Sydney.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p: To proof. **Marginal sentence to go in as a footnote – but check where: I sent you about 90 to 100 nearly a month ago. Sydney N. S. Wales

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
Pardon me my dear Baron I beg of you for not having long ago replied to your kind note of the 1st Inst.
See M to E. Strickland, 1 September 1887.
MS letter head what is it? 'SANS MAL'.
MS annotation: 'Re [...] [...] [...] the 1st Steam route connecting Great Britain with Australia was in 1852 via Suez and Singapore thence to K.G. Sound &c.'
The truth is that I am troubled with gout and a terrible despondency which unfits me for everything and makes me often very forgetful of social duties. It was very kind of you to write to me and I thank you for it very much. I do trust very sincerely that your health is recovering and that you are enjoying our lovely Spring weather — I always look upon Spring tide in Australia as the perfection of climate —

Judging from some papers sent to me from Adelaide the Geographical Congress seems to have been a great success — I really can find no words to express my regret and great disappointment at being unable to join the party — Antarctic exploration will I trust be carried out — from here I have no hopes of getting 1s towards defraying expenses and to my mind we must rely chiefly on private liberality for the necessary funds — I see that some munificent offers have been made at Adelaide — All this may lead to a reconsideration of the important subject at home and here and elsewhere, but as I said before I have no hopes from our Government.

There is a vast tract of unexplored country in Central and N. Western Australia which I should much wish to see visited by a competent explorer. I do hope it may not be long before I have the pleasure of seeing you — meanwhile pray believe me to be always

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I really cannot praise too much your admirably compiled book your [proceedings] — We shall be very glad here of some copies — I have another paper prepared here but I really have no heart to work here for our Society — If I could give it up with honor I would do so at once, but it is still in a mess therefore I am obliged to stand by it in the hour of need. If you can find time I wish that you would kindly write me a long letter telling me all about the Conference and epitomizing the result thereof — It strikes me that there ought to be a special vol. prepared descriptive of the whole event, and this all the more as it must ever form an important incident in the history of the Society in these Colonies —

Please tell me concerning map of these Colonies — Have you Stamfords's latest map ?
Reference?
which do you look upon as the best map of Australia —

I want to get the most modern maps of the world and of Australia giving [plainly] the sea routes and railways and if possible telegraph wires — also including all recent information of [...] and French conquests there and of [Afghanistan] boundary —
Please say what these ought to cost and in haste believe me to be ever

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: P.S. I am writing to Panton
